newsitem.title: JAPAN: JGB futures end higher ahead of long weekend.
newsitem.headline: JGB futures end higher ahead of long weekend.

text.p: The key March Japanese government bond (JGB) futures contract ended Friday's Tokyo session higher, but well off its earlier high of 126.41.
The March closed up 0.10 at 126.02, an intraday low. Volume was 43,904 contracts.
"The March gave up much of its gains on position-adjustment selling ahead of the long weekend," said a trader at a trust bank's securities unit.
Tokyo markets will be closed for a holiday on Monday.
Traders, however, said a solid support was confirmed near 126.00.

"The March looked heavy above 126.30 while looking solid around 126.00, as people were eager to square their positions before a three-day break. Next week, however, the March might test record highs," said a brokerage house trader.
The all-time high for any benchmark JGB futures contract is 126.58 recorded on November 28.
The recent weakness in Tokyo stocks is lending support to JGBs, as it underscored the likelihood that the Bank of Japan (BOJ) would need to maintain a low interest rate policy.
Tokyo's Nikkei 225 average ended up 119.79 points or 0.61 percent at 19,690.46 on Friday.
Traders said the Nikkei's failure to post bigger gains after a 126 point overnight jump in New York's Dow Jones industrial average suggested the weaknes in Tokyo stocks would continue for a while.
Some traders noted that the BOJ's monthly economic review was partly responsible for JGB selling in late afternoon.
The economy is continuing its gradual recovery, with private demand becoming increasingly firm, the central bank said in the report.
It also said the pace of the rise in industrial output is increasing.
Next week, market participants will be focusing on whether the BOJ will conduct an outright JGB purchase operation on Tuesday, traders said.
The BOJ currently conducts outright JGB purchase operations twice a month.
